articles.title: Something mysterious is lighting up the Milky Way. Could it be dark matter?
articles.description: Scientists at Johns Hopkins may be closing in on dark matter’s elusive trail, uncovering a mysterious gamma ray glow at the heart of our galaxy that could signal unseen matter colliding — or perhaps the frantic spin of dying stars. articles.description: Kap Paper announced the mill’s idling last month, citing a failure to obtain emergency government support

articles.description: The U.S. Commerce Department may be preparing to ease auto parts tariffs, providing partial relief to Canada’s automotive industry

articles.title: Is that photo real or fake? Digital ‘birth certificates’ are a new way to get answers
articles.description: Sony technology, tested by The Globe over months, seeks to create a virtual paper trail that AI-generated imagery can never match

articles.description: The Prime Minister is attempting to repair the relationship with Xi Jinping – without angering Donald Trump

articles.description: Stellantis’s decision to shift Jeep production south of the border highlights the challenge of keeping a thriving domestic industry

articles.title: Trump signs proclamation for 25 per cent tariff on trucks, with USMCA exemption
articles.description: Trucks compliant with the USMCA will be tariffed only on their non-American parts

articles.title: ZWAAGSTRA: Smith government should end teacher strike, but not with more money
articles.description: Alberta teachers are on strike and nobody knows how long this strike will last. The Alberta Teachers’ Association (ATA) claims public education is underfunded. articles.title: Letters, Oct. 11, 2025: ‘Disturbing development on social media’
articles.description: Horribly wrong Warren Kinsella’s article (‘Young people alarmingly pro-Hamas,’ Calgary Sun, Oct. 9) citing Harvard-Harris reporting that large percentages of Gen Z and Millennials have been brainwashed through social media’s relentless assault on the state of Israel and Jewish people eve

articles.title: Not only is Lake Powell's water level plummeting because of drought, its total capacity is shrinking, too
articles.description: Lake Powell, the second-largest human-made reservoir in the US, has lost nearly 7% of its potential storage capacity since 1963, when Glen Canyon Dam was built, a new report shows.

articles.title: Vietnam’s love affair with gas bikes is colliding with a new electric reality
articles.description: HANOI, Vietnam (AP) — Vietnam is split between two visions: the rumbling, reliable gas-powered motorbikes that now rule the roads, and sleek, silent electric bikes the government says are its future. Hanoi plans to ban fossil-fuel motorcycles from its city center in July 2026, part of a nation

articles.title: Japan’s LDP Reaches Coalition Deal to Set Up Takaichi as Premier
articles.description: Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party will sign a coalition deal with the Japan Innovation Party later Monday, according to the smaller party’s leader, a move that would set up Sanae Takaichi to become the country’s first female prime minister.

articles.title: Bolivia elects centre-right Rodrigo Paz as president
articles.description: Paz, the son of a former president, promises 'capitalism for all' as election ends 20 years of socialist government.

articles.title: Blue Jays force Game 7 in ALCS with 6-2 win
articles.description: Addison Barger and Vladimir Guerrero Jr. homered to power the Toronto Blue Jays to a 6-2 win over the Seattle Mariners on Sunday in Game 6 of the American League Championship Series.

articles.title: Israel says it will return to ceasefire after Gaza strikes
articles.description: Israel and Hamas accused one another of breaching the deal, which came into force on 10 October.

articles.title: China’s economy slows to 4.8% annual growth in July-September, hit by tariffs and slack demand
articles.description: HONG KONG (AP) — China’s economy expanded at the slowest annual pace in a year in July- September, growing 4.8%, weighed down by trade tensions with the United States and slack domestic demand. The July-September data was the weakest pace of growth since the third quarter of 2024, and co

articles.title: Japan’s Nikkei Set for New High Ahead of Prime Minister Vote
articles.description: Japanese stocks climbed Monday on heightened expectations that pro-stimulus Sanae Takaichi will be elected as the nation’s next prime minister. Easing concerns over US-China trade tensions also supported sentiment.
